Award.AwardTitle: Dynamics of Photogenerated Excitons, Charge Carriers and Reorientations of Chromophores in Photorefractive Polymeric Nanocomposites
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project aims to study the dynamics of various steps relevant to the occurrence of the photorefractive effect in hybrid polymeric nanocomposites containing quantum dots. The investigations will target the mechanisms of photogeneration and transport of charge carriers and the development of the refractive index grating in materials containing quantum dots acting as photosensitizers. The focus is on the process of photosensitization in the infrared to extend the photorefractive sensitivity to telecommunication wavelengths as well as on the process of multiexciton generation induced carrier multiplication to dramatically improve the photorefractive performance at shorter wavelengths. The nanocomposites will involve engineered semiconductor nanoparticles (quantum dots, QDs) such as nanopods, through attachment of the QDs to carbon nanotubes and through the use of mobility boosting components such as pentacene. The project will place emphasis on training of minority students and researchers, which is a priority at our university. They will be involved in highly multidisciplinary research involving nanotechnology, photonics and spectroscopy.

%%%

This project will impact broadly optoelectronics and photovoltaics, leading to better ultraviolet (UV) detectors using carrier multiplication, as well as broad band, highly efficient photovoltaic and solar cells capable of harvesting photons from UV to infrared (IR). The optoelectronic devices using carrier multiplication will be especially useful for space applications by efficiently using readily available deep UV photons. The project will place emphasis on training of minority students and researchers, which is a priority at our university.

The goal of the research under this grant for last four years was to develop efficient photorefractive polymer nanocomposite containing semi-conducting quantum dots and study the dynamics of photogenerated excitons and the optimization of charge carrier mobility in hybrid organic-inorganic nanocomposite intended for applications in photorefractive devices and also in solar cells, photodetectors, field-effect transistors, light-emitting diodes etc. Typically, the photorefractive polymer device consists of four necessary components including photoconductive polymer, nonlinear optic chromophore, plasticizer and photosensitizer. So far, the most commonly used photosensitizers in the photorefractive materials are fullerene and trinitrofluorenone (TNF) to lead to a formation of charge-transfer complex with donor-like molecules and polymers. Recently, CdSe nanocrystals are used as an alternative to organic sensitizers, due to higher photogeneration efficiency and photostability. However, those photosensitizers have the limitation for the practical application at telecommunication wavelength of 1310 nm.

This project has dealt with lead sulfide (PbS) nanocrystals used as the infrared-absorbing photosensitizer in photorefractive polymer devices. The focus is on the process of photosensitization in the infrared to extend the photorefractive sensitivity to telecommunication wavelengths. Another issue is the elucidation of the mechanism of carrier transport in a blend of polymer and PbS nanocrystals. Using the time-of-flight technique, we have shown nanoparticle-mediated enhancement of mobility in the system of PbS nanoparticles embedded in poly (N-vinylcarbazole) (PVK). As a continued work, we demonstrated the efficient photorefractive nanocomposite device and the practical application at telecommunication wavelength through the improved two beam coupling and photoconductivity experimental. We also showed the enhanced photorefractive response using facile surface treatment of PbS nanocrystals functionalized with thermally cleavable ligand. This ligand engineering approach would be very useful for other applications such as solar cells, photodetectors, field-effect transistors, light-emitting diodes etc. 

Two graduate students were mainly involved in this project. One of them graduated with PhD diploma through an international collaboration with Professor Yiping Cui at Southeast University in China. Our primary result was published in Applied physics letters, reporting the highest reported value for net gain at the operation wavelength of 1310 nm for photorefractive composite device. Other relevant works were successfully carried out to publish 6 more papers by partial support of this project. 7 publications resulted from this project.
